attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Length of feature in kilometers, calculated using PCS Arc 1950 UTM Zone 34S.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Area of feature in square kilometers, calculated using PCS Arc 1950 UTM Zone 34S.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Name of the country or subnational area (administrative division).
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Board on Geographic Names, 2019; Statistics Botswana, 2011

attr.attrdef: Concatenation of all administrative division names separated by underscores (“_”), beginning with the country name and ending with the division name for the lowest subnational administrative order (level). The field serves as one for name sorting and ordering.
Identical subnational area identifiers in the Unicode text table and geospatial data file, enabling linkage (joining) of the table records to the geospatial data file polygons as attributes.
First-order administrative division name (ADM1), i.e., districts, towns, and cities.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Board on Geographic Names, 2019; Statistics Botswana, 2011

attr.attrdef: Administrative level "0" (ADM0/country); administrative level "1" (ADM1); administrative level "2" (ADM2); administrative level "3" (ADM3); administrative level "4" (ADM4).
Any notes about a country or subnational division, which may include former names or alternate names or spellings.
U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC) Standard (for country and first-order administrative divisions only).
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC), 2019

attr.attrdef: U.S. Government Federal Information Processing System (FIPS) code (for country and first-order administrative divisions only).
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Government Federal Information Processing System (FIPS), 2019

dataIdInfo.idAbs: Annual Five-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for 2000 to 2025 for the national and first-order administrative division levels of Botswana were prepared by the U.S. Census Bureau for joining (linking) to shapefiles as attribute data. The estimates are consistent with the midyear national projections from the U.S. Census Bureau International Data Base (IDB).
dataIdInfo.idPurp: The U.S. Census Bureau is providing annual subnational five-year age group population estimates by sex for 2000-2025 in a geographic information system (GIS) for users of the Spatial Data Repository, funded by the U.S. President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR).
dataIdInfo.idCredit:
CENSUS DATA
Age-Sex data: Population and Housing Census 2011 Microdata. Statistics Botswana. Acquired from Statistics Botswana by request of USCB staff at http://botswana.microdatahub.com/index.php/catalog/15 (acquired May 22, 2019); Population & Housing Census 2011: National Statistical Tables, Table 12. Distribution of Population by District, Sex and Five Years Age Groups. Statistics Botswana. Available online at http://www.statsbots.org.bw/sites/default/files/publications/national_statisticsreport.pdf (accessed August 15, 2019); 2011 Population and Housing Census: Population of Towns, Villages and Associated Localities. Statistics Botswana. Available online at http://www.statsbots.org.bw/sites/default/files/2011%20Population%20and%20Housing%20Census%20%28Results%29.pdf (accessed August 15, 2019); 2001 Population and Housing Census: Population of Towns, Villages and Associated Localities. Statistics Botswana. Available online at http://www.statsbots.org.bw/sites/default/files/publications/population_town.pdf (accessed August 15, 2019). The U.S. Census Bureau cannot guarantee the accuracy of non-U.S. census and survey data.
GEOSPATIAL BOUNDARIES
International boundaries coincide with the Large Scale International Boundaries (LSIB) dataset from the U.S. Department of State, Office of the Geographer and Global Issues. Available online at http://geonode.state.gov (accessed 2019). Geospatial data for the first-order administrative divisions of Botswana were digitized by USCB staff from enumeration area maps found in the 1981 Population and Housing Census: Guide to the Villages and Towns of Botswana, acquired from the U.S. Census Bureau Library, and the Botswana National Spatial Plan 2036, available online at http://www.botsreal.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/Draft-NSP-summary-BotsReal.pdf (accessed August 15, 2019). The U.S. Census Bureau cannot guarantee the accuracy of boundary placements.
NATIONAL ESTIMATES AND PROJECTIONS
U.S. Census Bureau, Population Division. INTERNATIONAL DATA BASE, September 2018 release, available at http://www.census.gov/data-tools/demo/idb/informationGateway.php, accessed in August 2019.
NATIONAL AND SUBNATIONAL AREA NAMES AND CODES
(1) U.S. National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency. NGA GEOnet Names Server (GNS), available at http://geonames.nga.mil/gns/html/, accessed in August 2019. For geographic area names from the U.S. Board on Geographic Names and the U.S. Government Federal Information Processing System (FIPS) codes. (2) U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC) Standard. NSG Standards Registry, available at http://nsgreg.nga.mil/genc/discovery, accessed in August 2019.

Consts.useLimit: U.S. Census Bureau population estimates: None. Acknowledgment of the Census Bureau would be appreciated in products derived from its population estimates. The subnational boundaries used for this shapefile were digitized by the U.S. Census Bureau to be made public for this product. The international boundaries are derived from the Large Scale International Boundaries (LSIB) dataset (public domain).

dataIdInfo.suppInfo:
SUBNATIONAL DIVISIONS
Botswana's first-order administrative divisions: 17 districts, towns, and cities as of the 2011 census.
SHAPEFILES
The shapefile created by USCB staff had 519 polygons and matched the 2011 villages and unaffiliated localities (ADM3). The U.S. Census Bureau aligned the boundaries in the shapefile to the “Large Scale International Boundary Line” (LSIB) polygon file (2018) from the U.S. Department of State, Office of the Geographer and Global Issues. Then, the Census Bureau dissolved the LSIB-aligned shapefile into 17 polygons for Botswana's first-order administrative divisions. The final shapefile contains 17 polygons, one for each of Botswana's first-order administrative divisions (districts, towns, and cities) as reported by Statistics Botswana in the 2011 census.
Notes: (1) A number of localities (fourth-order) became villages (third-order) between the 2001 and 2011 censuses, as noted in the "USCBCMNT" field. 2001 populations for these localities can be found in the report Population & Housing Census 2001: Population of Towns, Villages and Associated Localities, and were subtracted from their parent villages by U.S. Census Bureau staff. (2) A few villages split off to form new areas between the 2001 and 2011 censuses, as noted in the "USCBCMNT" field, requiring interpolation and adjustment of 2001 population data by USCB staff. For new areas fully formed from part of a single original municipal district, the total population of the original area was divided proportionally according to the populations of the same areas in 2011. For new areas that were formed from parts of multiple original villages, the total population of the new area was divided proportionally according to the land areas of the multiple original pieces in square kilometers. (3) Botswana also contains many "localities with no affiliation," which are not administratively part of any village. Two of these unaffiliated localities, BDF Mogoditshane and Thebephatshwa, are military bases that were treated as villages for this data product by USCB staff. Most of the other unaffiliated localities were limited in size and contained very small populations, which were added to the nearest village by USCB staff, noted in the "USCBCMNT" field as "includes localities with no village affiliation." However, groups of some of the unaffiliated localities either contained more substantial populations, or encompassed a larger geographical area, and were collectively treated as third-order administrative divisions for this data product, noted in the "USCBCMNT" field as "only localities with no village affiliation." The names collectively assigned to these groups of unaffiliated localities by USCB staff were taken from the report 1981 Population and Housing Census: Guide to the Villages and Towns of Botswana, in the U.S. Census Bureau Library. This report also contained the maps that were digitized by USCB staff to create the shapefiles used in this data product. (4) The town of Orapa is considered to be a first-order administrative division by Statistics Botswana, and was listed as such by USCB staff for this data product. It is not considered to be a first-order administrative division according to the U.S. Government Geopolitical Entities, Names, and Codes (GENC) standards, and therefore has no associated GENC code in this data product. (5) The six villages of Ngamiland Delta were combined for this data product by USCB staff because third-order boundaries for the area could not be located.
FEATURE AND ATTRIBUTE DETAILS
The 2000-2025 population estimates for Botswana's administrative divisions are provided in the following 2 tables: The Unicode tab-delimited text file (table) "Botswana_5yr_age_sex_2000-2025_uscb_sep2019.txt," which can be joined to the shapefile via the common field "GEO_MATCH." The Excel table "Botswana_5yr_age_sex_2000-2025_508_uscb_sep2019.xlsx," formatted for accessibility in compliance with Section 508 of the U.S. Government's Federal Rehabilitation Act.
Details on processing of the census data and calculation of 2000-2025 estimates are provided in the "Census_Metadata" tab of the Excel file and "Methods for Calculating 5-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for Subnational Areas" document.
For the subnational areas, the U.S. Board on Geographic Names (BGN) "approved" names from the NGA GEOnet Names Server (cited in the "Credits") were used. For any area that a BGN name was not available, the name from the national census was used. Official codes for the subnational areas from the country's national statistical office, when available, are entered in the "NSO_CODE" field in both the text and Excel tables. Information on any alternative area names or recent name or boundary changes is entered in the "USCBCMNT" field.
A partial list of the fields in the Excel and Unicode text files, including all fields identifying geographic names and codes, is provided in the Excel file's "Data_Dictionary" tab.
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
More detail on the U.S. Census Bureau subnational age and sex group estimates and maps for PEPFAR can be found in the document "Subnational Population Estimates Components for the Spatial Data Repository." It includes a data dictionary that is similar to that in the Excel table.
ACCESS
The U.S. Census Bureau’s products for PEPFAR can be accessed from the SPATIAL DATA REPOSITORY:
Zipped file containing geographic boundary data, tables with subnational population estimates, and instructions for linking (joining) the text file to the geographic boundary data: http://spatialdata.dhsprogram.com/home/. This web address also provides access to data and maps from the DHS (Demographic and Health Surveys) Program.
Instructions for linking (joining) the text file to the geographic boundary data can also be found in a standalone methodology document in the Spatial Data Repository.
For more information, see the following methodology documents in the Spatial Data Repository: (1) "Subnational Population Estimates Components for the Spatial Data Repository." (2) "Methods for Calculating 5-Year Age Group Population Estimates by Sex for Subnational Areas."
All of the above documents, tables, and geographic boundary data (zipped) are also available on the Census Bureau website at http://www.census.gov/geographies/mapping-files/time-series/demo/international-programs/subnationalpopulation.html for download.
